title: Winnipeg's business leaders want the city to regulate handbills - Winnipeg Free Press
text:
City hall needs to crack down on the proliferation of handbills throughout its prominent neighbourhoods.
Leaders from several Business Improvement Zones asked a civic committee Friday morning to rein in the spread of handbills that are problematic to remove, damage decorative poles and are considered an eyesore.
"When you’re driving down different streets, seeing different areas and constantly seeing the postering issue problem – it really is unsightly and it doesn’t look great for our city," Stephanie Meilleur, executive director of the Osborne Village BIZ, said.
The BIZ groups said handbills promoting community events, local bands and other functions are plastered everywhere – on light poles, waste bins, buildings.
The promoters don’t remove the handbills, forcing the BIZ groups to hire staff to do the work.
Gloria Cardwell-Hoeppner, executive director of the West End BIZ, said the Supreme Court of Canada upheld the right of individuals and groups to post handbills but municipalities have the right to enforce how they are posted and require their removal.
But the BIZ groups said promoters seldom remove the handbills, city enforcement is lax, with the result that the BIZ groups hire staff to remove.
Ironically, they said one of the city’s regulations is compounding the problem – handbills can only be placed with clear tape but the tape is difficult to remove and damages the surface area of decorative fixtures that they’re attached to.
Meilleur said sometimes the handbills are three inches thick on some poles in the village neighbourhood.
"I’m spending a lot more money out of my budget removing the posters, having to put staff on the street to remove those posters, the cost then that goes into fixing the poles once they are removed," Meilleur said.
Cardwell-Hoeppner said other municipalities – Calgary, Vancouver and Ottawa – have effectively regulated the postering of handbills and urged the city to adopt similar methods.
The BIZ groups suggested that they will provide bulletin boards in their neighbourhoods where the handbills can be posted, and wanted city hall to amend bylaws to make it illegal to post the handbills anywhere else and to crack down on violators.
Meilleur said that unless city hall and the BIZ groups do not provide appropriate, alternate locations for the handbills, they will continue to be posted where no one wants them.
Councillors on the protection and community services committee instructed the administration to work with the BIZ groups to address the problems, including reviewing how other municipalities have dealt with the issue.
